segments.text: This is a test.
Today's date is March 10th, 1981.
This is an interview with Dean George Shelton.
This is an interview.
Well, George Shelton, Dean of the College of Veterinary Medicine, today's date is Tuesday, March 10th, 1981.
Let's start with your personal background.
Can you tell us about your early years in Steavenville, Texas?
Yes, I grew up in Steavenville, Texas in the Depression years and on a small farm south of Steavenville and completed high school at Steavenville High School.
And then attended what was then a branch of Texas A&M University called John Tarleton Agricultural College in those days.
And you tell us about your parents.
Let's slow down here for a minute.
All right.
My parents were farm people.
And my father was a small farmer, mixed farming, a little bit of everything, dairy and row crops, peanuts.
my mother was just a farm wife, housewife.
I had one sister who was seven years younger than, five years younger than I, and she also completed high school at Stephenville and then went on to John Tarleton for two years.
What kind of education did your parents have?
My parents were, had only a grade school education.
They completed
Oh, something like seventh grade, something of that period.
They had lived in the Stephenville area most of their life.
My mother came from East Texas, grew up around Sulphur Springs, and then they had lived on farms around Stephenville for most of their life.
No, you grew up during the Depression.
What was the impact of the Depression on you and on your family?
Well, it was a fairly drastic impact, although in those days it wasn't as severe as a Depression would be today because we lived on a 200-acre farm and we weren't affected
very much by the energy problem because we didn't have all that much energy.
In the early years, we didn't even have electricity.
And then after the REA came into the communities, we did get electricity.
But in the very heart of the Depression, we were still using draft animals, horses and mules to farm with.
And so while the
depression hurt as far as having money for capital development.
It didn't really hurt all that much as far as our life was concerned.
We always had food and we didn't have much money, but then very few people did.
We always had
the essentials, food, clothing, and shelter.
Clothing might not have been too good, but we always had it.
And so our life was not drastically affected by the Depression, except there just was no growth, no capital development.
And every year was sort of like the last one.
The worst year I can remember was 1934,
the drought hit so bad in that area of Texas, well all over Texas.
That year was rough.
Did you grow anything?
We grew almost nothing except some vegetables and foodstuff, but we had nothing to sell that year.
There was no sales because we didn't produce anything.
It was lucky to keep going.
It was lucky to keep fed, probably.
And fortunately, we lived in a sandy area where we did raise some vegetables, and we were able to get a little bit of a hay crop before it got so terribly hot and dry.
So we survived 1934, but it was a bad year.
That was the year that the federal government began to start so many social or
socioeconomic programs to one that I remember that had some bearing on me as a small boy was the government bought cattle under some kind of a federal program.
They actually would take so many of the cattle that the farmer had and they just dig long trenches somewhere in the countryside and shoot the cattle.
and pay something like $8 or $10 a piece for them.
And while that today, it reduced the supply of cattle and gave the farmer a little bit of capital.
By today's standards, nothing.
But in those days, $10 was
Kind of an unbelievable amount of money.
Concerning bacon, went for a nickel a pound.
Yeah.
So the prices, too, on the other end of the farmer, they must have just really hurt you as far as the devaluation of prices for selling your farm crops.
Value, almost.
Products were just not worth much.
But surprisingly enough, people did survive.
because their standards of living were so much lower than today.
I didn't expect much.
Today, I suppose anyone my age that remembers the Great Depression, and I was small, but I remember it very vividly.
Of course, we didn't really get out of it until about 1938 to 40.
But I can remember the years of 34, 35 very well.
And anyone that remembers those days can't help but suddenly sometimes stop and think, what would happen if that happened today?
Where would people go?
You know, when, what, 80% or 70% to 80% of our people live in huge urban areas like Houston, Dallas, and Los Angeles.
What would those people do?
I really don't know.
Now in those, in 1934, I suppose 70 or 80% of the people lived in small towns and rural, and on little farms.
And I suppose in that time, we still probably had better than six to seven million farms.
But the call farms wouldn't be farmed by today's standards, but at least the people were out where they could get food.
The people that were heard in the 32 to 36 era were the people in New York City and Chicago and the bread lines.
They had no food.
No jobs, no money.
What influence did your parents have on you?
I guess, well, a very, very positive influence because my parents were always dedicated to the importance of education.
They believed that a young person, myself and my sister, the only chance that we had for a good life or a better life was through education.
Even though they didn't have any.
Even though their education was relatively poor, relatively limited.
They both were very, very devoted to the importance of education.
How can you account for that?
Was it part of the American dream?
I think it was part of the American dream for that time, and I don't think my parents were all that much different from their peers, their contemporaries.
I think that people on the small farms of
Middle America in those days valued education.
Most of them had people the age of my mother and father, a high school education was considered pretty outstanding.
That's certainly better than a college degree today, in that day.
So while they didn't have a lot of education, they had enough to know the importance
I guess that's how I would put it.
They were hardworking people, Christian people dedicated to the basic values, moral values of America.
And they were upward motivated in the sense that they wanted a better life for us than they had.
So yes, they had a positive influence, very definitely.
My father was a strict disciplinarian who, while he was always reasonable and understanding with me, I knew what he expected of me, too.
So they had a very positive effect.
And is that why you decided to go to college then?
I guess I never thought about anything else.
I never recall ever having any other goal.
Now, I didn't know that I would go on to finish a professional degree and a PhD and all that kind of stuff.
You know, I didn't know what that was in those days.
But I always knew that I was going to get a college degree.
I'd finish high school, and somehow I'd get a college degree.
So when you finished high school, there really wasn't another alternative for you.
I never considered one.
You had just decided, yeah.
I never considered one.
I just immediately enrolled there.
Of course, we had the advantage of being able to live at home and go to that junior college for two years, which I did.
I lived at home.
I didn't move to the city.
I continued to work on the farm.
I'd get up and hand milk.
In those days...
a dozen cows before going to school in the morning.
After school, I went home.
Those two years of college were sort of an extension of high school for me because I would go, I pretty much followed the same pattern of life those two years of college that I did in high school.
And I continued to work and to earn as much of my
way as I could.
I worked on the, I generally worked on the farm in the summer, but summer of 1940 and 41, I did work for the REA.
Really?
Through the summer to earn a little extra money.
Putting up telephone poles, wires, and stuff like that?
Yeah.
Bringing electricity out to the farms?
That's right, yeah.
That was in adding there.
Maybe not all.
These were just extra jobs.
Yeah, a government job.
Was a government job hard to get?
Well, they had loosened up.
They weren't so hard to get by 40, 39, 40, 41.
No, they had been.
Well, they'd been impossible to get back in the early 30s.
But by the late 30s and early 40s, no, you could get jobs.

You know, I saw the Grapes of Wrath about a month ago again, and the whole idea of the government was a very benevolent type government, and today we have so many politicians blaming Washington for this and blaming Washington for that.
Would you agree with that?
Did it seem back then that it was a positive force in American history?
I thought so.
Because having
having a memory over the spectrum of years and the federal programs, I'm sort of a pro-Roosevelt person.
I realize that on through the next 40 years some of the federal programs and the idea that the government could do everything is carried way too far.
But I still
take issue with people that are too critical of Roosevelt for the, what do you call it, the Great Society, or that wasn't it, but... New Deal.
The New Deal, yeah.
The Great Society was LBJ.
Yes, that's LBJ.
But it's all a continuation of the spectrum.
And the New Deal, as far as I'm concerned, was a very positive and a very good force.
And I would tend to think that if Roosevelt was the kind of man that would have seen, after a while it was going too far.
Because I was a respecter of Roosevelt.
I thought he was a brilliant man.
I realize that there's some things that history maybe shows that he might have been wrong and maybe did wrong.
But I certainly thought that his New Deal
was a positive effort, and overall it was positive.
There's so many things like the GI Bill of Rights.
When you try to balance the strong against the good against the bad, boy, it wins out hands down.
And I tend to think the New Deal did, too.
The government effort to get the country moving forward again.
I surely see that
It was overdone, and it's been carried too far in places.
And of course, we all know that some of those federal programs like the REA and several things, you know, perhaps Roosevelt tried to stack the Supreme Court.
I guess he did, you know.
And he probably went too far in some of those because that might have been almost dictatorial.
There was a need to move the country forward in 1932.
Yeah, for sure.
By some means or other.
Now when you were at junior college, did you have any idea that you wanted to become a veterinarian?
Yes, yes I did.
There was a veterinarian in Stephenville by the name of Vern Scott who had been to my father's farm
all through the years since I was big enough to remember.
He was a very strong force on so many young men in the area of Stephenville in those years.
I suppose contributed to a dozen or 20 young people coming to Texas A&M to study veterinary medicine.
Was he an A&M grad?
No, he wasn't.
Well, let me back up.
He was an A&M graduate, but he received his veterinary degree from the old private school in Kansas City, Kansas City Veterinary College.
But Dr. Scott had finished A&M in animal husbandry.
And that was along about the time the new school was started here.
And for whatever reason, he did not go to veterinary school here, but went to Kansas City.
But he was an A&M grad and a strong supporter of A&M.
And he was a good image, a flamboyant, strong personality, strong will.
And he taught animal science or animal husbandry at Tarleton.
Oh, he did.
So he was a vet and he taught.
He was a practicing veterinarian.
He was a practicing veterinarian and taught part time there in the school.
He had what in those days was an ideal job.
He had the best of all worlds.
Yes, he was.
So he was a strong influence.
What's your background?
Did that play a role since you came from a farm?
I don't know what hit you.
I'm not sure.
For you, what about your background?
Was that another factor?
Oh, I think so, yes.
I was going to spend my life somewhere in the agricultural industry, either in the animal science or plant science, somewhere.
I knew that from, you know, I'm sure that was a factor.
then Dr. Scott probably was a positive influence to go into the animal side of things.
And even in 1941, when I started to Tarleton, perhaps I think I wanted to be a veterinarian then, but I didn't know if I could ever get through.
I didn't know what the finances would be.
I knew it would be terribly expensive
By my standards, by the monies I had, it would be difficult to come to Texas A&M.
So in 1941, I took the pre-veterinary curriculum at Tarleton, but I didn't know if I'd ever get through or not.
I hoped to, and I planned to, but those days were a little different than today because of the loan programs that are available to young people.
We didn't have any loan programs available to us.
So we had to earn our own way.
Our parents had to find the money.
I didn't know whether I could get through or not.
My goal was sort of a short term, to get through Tarleton, finish the pre-vet requirement, and then cross the next bridge when I got there.
And when you were at Tarleton, was that for two years?
I know you went in the Army Air Force in 1942.
So were you done with your pre-vet curriculum?
Yes.
See, I started at Tarleton in the fall of 1941, and the war broke out in December.
They immediately switched to an accelerated program.
Oh, I see.
So by December of 1942, I had essentially completed two years' work.
I looked then at the possibility of coming on to Texas A&M.
They had at that time what was called an ASTP program, Army Specialized Training Program.
And I looked into that, came to Texas A&M, talked to some of the young veterinary students at the time, and everything was so terribly uncertain.
In December 1942, they had stopped enlistments.
You could no longer enlist in any of the armed services.
Everybody was being drafted because they were getting lopsided situations.

Some people wanted to enlist in this force or that force, so you had to go on through the draft, and I elected to, then I went back home at Christmas time, and I elected to go on in the draft because I didn't think I could ever get through here.
People were being called up almost every day.
Oh, really?
It was a demoralized crew, you know.
You didn't know if you'd be in school one more week or one more year.
Now, some students did stay in school and did finish.
But I elected to go on.
So I went home about, oh, I don't know, I suppose it was 15th or 20th of December.
And I went down to the draft board and told them, you know, I wasn't going to apply for an extension because I wasn't going on to A&M.
You could apply for an extension.
a delay, really, I say extension, a delay of the draft.
So I went home and told them I wasn't going to.
They were happy to hear that.
Yeah, they announced at Tarleton just before Christmas that anybody that was drafted over the holidays would not have to take final exams.
And I thought, well, if I'm going on this service, I don't want to take the final exam.
So I went out to the draft board and told them I wasn't going to ask for a delay.
So, man, they moved fast.
I went to Camp Barkley, I believe it was what they called it, in Abilene and was inducted into the Army on December 29th.
They didn't delay.
It's kind of unbelievable.
How'd you get in the Army Air Force?
Did you apply for that?
They assigned me.
Oh, they just assigned you.
What was your job?
We had no choice.
You didn't know if you were going to infantry or Navy or Marines or where.
So we went to Camp Walters, I think about the 3rd of January of 1943.
We were inducted and sent home for three days or so, a weekend kind of thing, and then reported to Camp Walters.
I went through an induction center there, and the first thing I knew, I'd been signed to the Air Force.
But I had no idea where I was going.
Did they train you, or did they give you a job?
No, we went through a brief orientation at Camp Walters, sent me to Shepherd Field, Texas, to the Air Force base.
and a very brief basic training program there, something like two months.
And then I went to Scottfield, Illinois for radio operator gunnery school.
I had applied for pilot's training, but failed to pass the physical exam because of an eye problem, a little bit of a defective eye problem.
I don't know whether that was really it or whether they had more people applying for pilot training than they needed.
There probably were quite a few.
Yes.
So anyhow, I went on to Scott Field in radio operator gunnery school.
Completed there with radio operator mechanic school, they called it.
And then from there to gunnery school in Las Vegas, Nevada.
and then to what they call a replacement training unit for gunnery crew or aircraft crew along by November of that year.
And then I was ready to take a place in replacement crew training.
See, the war was hot and heavy in both the Pacific and in Europe by that time, late 1943, early 1944.
And so I went through replacement training unit in Myrtle Beach, or in Columbia and Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, and then was shipped to the Pacific in early 1944.
Whereabouts in the South Pacific?
Well, almost the whole thing.
I started, of course, I reported to the Solomon Islands in Guadalcanal area, then was immediately moved to New Guinea and went through all the New Guinea campaigns.
or most of it, and then on up through the Philippines, and I completed my tour of duty just about the time the Philippine War was over.
It was all pretty well under control, and I left the Philippines in late April, early May 1945, and everybody- Did you occupy Japan?
I didn't go on to Japan.
They sent me home, and then I was ready to be reassigned to, I had flown on medium bombers in all the New Guinea, Philippine campaign.
And so when they sent me home for what they call rest and rehabilitation leave, and I would have been reassigned to B-29s.
Those were the big superfortress.
They dropped the bombs.
Yeah.
And then in August,
1945, when the war ended, I'm sure I would have reported to B-29 training program.
If the war had not ended in Europe, I would have reported by the middle of 1st of September.
And so you didn't have any leave for about two years then?
You had no leave for about two years?
Oh, minor leave, a week or so.
But you never got home for a couple of years, and that's why they sent you back.
No, they gave me a week, about a week or ten days, when I came back from Pacific.
That was in May, June 1945.
Then they assigned me to Ellington Field in Houston.
I was more or less in a delayed program there.
They were thinking about what they're going to do with it.
Yeah, well, of course, they anticipated.
They knew the war was over against Germany, and they anticipated another year and a half.
Oh, yeah.
I think the feeling, at least it got down to us, the feeling was that the war with Japan would last another year, 18 months.
And I certainly didn't agree with it.
I had been through all the New Guinea and Philippine campaign, and they didn't quit.
You just had to kill the last one.
And I assumed it would take a year, 18 months.
Now when you came back from the war, were your plans to go to Texas A&M?
Or how did that- You know, it's kind of ironic there.
When I came back in 45, I really never thought much about it because I didn't really think the war was over.
So I never gave much thought.
And it wasn't until about mid-August that I did, because I think the war ended in Japan about the 14th of August, something like that.
And all of a sudden, what am I going to do here?
I hadn't really thought much about it.
Oh, I guess sometimes in bull sessions in the barracks or somewhere, I'd like to.
At that time, they began to talk about the GI Bill.
Well, if I can qualify for the GI Bill, I think I'll go to Texas A&M and try to get in vet school.
And so as late as the middle of August, I hadn't thought much about it.
And then all of a sudden, I did.
So when the war ended, we still assumed that it would be several months before we could be mustered out.
word to use then.

And I really recall a time or two thinking that I'd come up to Texas A&M, I was down there in Houston, and talk to the school, but things began to move so fast, you know, after that, and all of a sudden realized that, man, we may get out of here.
So the war ended on August the 14th, and I was discharged on September 22nd.
That's tremendous.
It started at the Veterinary School here on September 27th.
Really?
But tell me about when you came up and getting admitted in five days.
Well, I had kind of a, I guess I was lucky.
Number one in the mustering out process, I had been through a lot of battle zones and had flown in several battle areas.
I'd been, I'd received, as everybody in the Air Force did, a number of medals and awards and so forth that they gave you points for.
Yeah.
So suddenly, I found I had enough points to be mustered out early.
And so I concentrated on getting out for a few days.
And then...
When they discharged me, my home was in Stephenville, and I was released at Ellington Field.
And I had purchased a little car back in the summer, that summer after coming back from Europe, I mean the Pacific.
I purchased a little car.
It was an old 36 Plymouth, I remember it.
And I couldn't keep it running because there was something wrong with it all the time.
It had 150,000 on it, I guess.
But anyway, I got it to run enough that I started home.
So I stopped by here at the college on the way home.
And that would have been like the 23rd or so.
And went over to see Dean Marsteller, who was dean at the college at the time.
